items.title: Texas A&M Tightens Rules on Talking About Race and Gender in Classes
items.summary: The university system will ban advocacy of “race or gender ideology, or topics related to sexual orientation or gender identity” without approval.

items.title: Indiana Professor Removed From Class Over White Supremacy Lesson
items.summary: The professor will no longer be able to teach a class on diversity after she showed students a diagram that included the “Make America Great Again” slogan as an example of white supremacy.

items.title: SNAP Benefits Are Resuming as Government Reopens After Shutdown
items.summary: Several states have restarted food stamp payments, but millions of Americans are still awaiting the November deposits that the Trump administration resisted paying out in full.

items.title: SNAP’s Problems Started Long Before the Shutdown
items.summary: The government shutdown caused a panic among recipients, but the monthly budgeting issues go back 50 years and may get worse.

items.title: After Trump Split, Epstein Said He Could ‘Take Him Down’
items.summary: Jeffrey Epstein cast himself as a Trump insider and wanted to leverage potentially damaging information about the president and his business dealings, according to emails with associates.

items.title: Epstein’s Emails About Trump
items.summary: Our investigative reporter Steve Eder provides context about Jeffrey Epstein’s relationship with President Donald Trump based on information from over 20,000 pages of documents from Epstein’s estate released by the House Oversight Committee on Wednesday.

items.title: What Epstein’s Emails Claim About Trump’s Knowledge of His Conduct
items.summary: The House Oversight Committee on Wednesday released more than 20,000 pages of documents from Jeffrey Epstein’s estate. Times reporters provide context on key emails.

items.title: What’s Behind the Coming House Vote on Releasing the Epstein Files
items.summary: Proponents of fuller transparency used an arcane rule to prod their leaders to act. When it became clear they had succeeded, the speaker agreed to hold a vote.

items.title: Former Prince Andrew and Another Prominent Briton Come Up in the Epstein Emails
items.summary: Newly released files from Jeffrey Epstein include correspondence with Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor and Peter Mandelson, the former British ambassador to Washington.

items.title: How a 17-Year-Old Girl Became Enmeshed in the Matt Gaetz Scandal
items.summary: A 17-year-old with a homeless parent wanted money for braces and ended up having sex for money with powerful men. She wants the public to have a fuller understanding of how she was victimized.

items.title: U.S. Officials Raise Concerns About Saudi Arabia’s Bid for F-35 Jets
items.summary: A Pentagon intelligence report says China could try to acquire advanced F-35 technology in Saudi Arabia if the Trump administration sells jets to the kingdom.

items.title: Why Can’t We Fix Penn Station?
items.summary: The biggest thing holding Penn Station back from a much-needed rehaul is what’s on top of it: Madison Square Garden.

items.title: Family of Fisherman Killed in U.S. Military Strike Says It Wants Justice
items.summary: Colombia was a top U.S. ally in Latin America until the Trump administration began deadly strikes in international waters. Now, one family wants justice.

items.title: BBC Apologizes to Trump Over Film Edit but Declines to Pay Compensation
items.summary: The BBC said it would not rebroadcast a misleadingly edited documentary but added, “We strongly disagree there is a basis for a defamation claim.”

items.title: At 97, the Bard of Albany Still Spins Tales of Gangsters and Politicians
items.summary: William Kennedy raised money for the food pantry at his old church by reading from “Legs,” the gangster novel he began his celebrated Albany cycle with half a century ago.

items.title: Katie Wilson, a Political Newcomer, Is Elected Mayor in Seattle
items.summary: Ms. Wilson, a self-described socialist, joined the race after Mayor Bruce Harrell opposed taxing high-income residents to finance construction of new housing.

items.title: Seattle Elects a Left-Wing Mayor With a Light Résumé but Mamdani Appeal
items.summary: Katie Wilson, who narrowly defeated the incumbent, Bruce Harrell, emerged from the city’s left-wing activist class and brings with her little experience in governing.

items.title: Blue Origin Lands Booster After Rocket Launch and Matches SpaceX’s Feat
items.summary: The lower half of the New Glenn rocket set down on a platform in the Atlantic Ocean after lifting a small NASA Mars mission to space.

items.title: Israeli Settlers Burn West Bank Mosque Amid Rise in Violent Attacks
items.summary: Since the 2023 attack on Israel by Hamas, growing settler violence and Israeli attacks on Palestinian militants have thrown the West Bank into turmoil and displaced tens of thousands.

items.title: Infant Formula Company Tied to Botulism Outbreak Had Known Problems
items.summary: A Pennsylvania plant run by the company, ByHeart, was shut down this year after inspectors found mold, a leaking roof and more than 2,500 dead insects in a food production area.

items.title: Hochul Vetoed 7 of His Bills in a Single Day. Could It Be Personal?
items.summary: State Senator James Skoufis of New York has been a steady critic of Gov. Kathy Hochul, a fellow Democrat. Her vetoes of his bills seemed intended to send a message.

items.title: Hochul Approved Permits That Could Help Clients of Her Husband’s Firm
items.summary: Opponents of a natural gas pipeline approved by Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York noted that the project would benefit a client of the prominent law firm where her husband works.

items.title: Wifredo Lam: Artist-Poet of Tropical Dreams and Sorrows
items.summary: The great Cuban modernist, whose politics and Afro-Asian roots shaped his paintings and inspired generations of artists, gets a revelatory survey at MoMA.

items.title: An Alternative to Christian Nationalism
items.summary: Once you put people into categorical boxes, you are inviting them to see history as a zero-sum conflict between this group and that one.

items.title: Maurene Comey’s Case Is More Consequential Than Her Father’s
items.summary: What James and Maurene Comey’s cases tell us about President Trump.

items.title: Jim Avila, Former ABC News Correspondent, Dies at 70
items.summary: He spent almost two decades at the network, covering a wide range of court cases and the White House. He was also at the center of a defamation lawsuit over “pink slime.”

items.title: Fetterman, Senator Who Survived Stroke, Hospitalized After Fall
items.summary: Senator John Fetterman, the hoodie-wearing Pennsylvanian who nearly died during his campaign and was later hospitalized for clinical depression, had minor injuries, according to his office.

items.title: Oklahoma Governor Commutes Inmate’s Death Sentence Just Before Execution
items.summary: The death-row inmate, Tremane Wood, 46, had already had his last meal. It was only the second time Gov. Kevin Stitt has stepped in to stop an execution.

items.title: Southern California Is Forecast to Get Heavy Rain
items.summary: Parts of Los Angeles County will be under evacuation warnings starting Thursday evening as a complex storm system moves in.
